Award.AwardTitle: Travel Support to Attend International Conference in Geodynamical Phenomena held in Kiev, Ukraine
Award.AbstractNarration: This is the second meeting of Slavic and US geoscientists to be help September, 2010 in Kiev, Ukraine. The topics covered will be broad in scope and concerns multiscale geodynamics of crustal, mantle and core dynamics from various perspectives. Mineral physics of all pressure ranges, numerical modeling of dynamic processes and computational seismology will be on the table. The meeting will also cover some new developments from GPU and multi-core computing as well as large dataset management. This meeting will provide the chance for junior scientists from USA to interact with Eastern European scientists from Ukraine and Russia and other countries.

Institution.Name: University of Minnesota-Twin Cities
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

POR.DRECONTENT:
In September 25 to 26, an international meeting in solid-earth geophysics was held in Kiev, Ukraine. This meeting was the first of its kind since Ukraine had

declared its independence from the Soviet Union in 1993. The NSF funds allow us to bring 14 American participants, which was attended by over 100 people

as shown in the photograph. We had people coming from all over the

former Republics of the Soviet Union , in addition to people coming from Europe, Australia and China. We had two undergraduate students

from the Minnesota and 6 graduate students from US institutions, from Scripps

Institution of Oceanography, Yale University, and the University of Minnesota.

Talks were given in the following subjects: deep earth geophysics, mantle dynamics, seismology, earthquakes and earth's rotation, and also GPU computing. radiative heat transfer, boundary-element method, subduction dynamics, high Rayleigh number convection. seismic tomography.

There were some serious scientific discussions among the various groups of participants. The group was led on an excursion along the Dnieper River and the museum of technical history. The Ukranians displayed considerable hospitality. The abstracts were published by an Ukranian journal in geophysics. We plan to have another meeting like this in the next two years.


Last Modified: 02/24/2012
Modified by: David A Yuen

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: In September 25 to 26, an international meeting in solid-earth geophysics was held in Kiev, Ukraine. This meeting was the first of its kind since Ukraine had declared its independence from the Soviet Union in 1993. The NSF funds allow us to bring 14 American participants, which was attended by over 100 people as shown in the photograph. We had people coming from all over the former Republics of the Soviet Union , in addition to people coming from Europe, Australia and China. We had two undergraduate students from the Minnesota and 6 graduate students from US institutions, from Scripps Institution of Oceanography, Yale University, and the University of Minnesota. Talks were given in the following subjects: deep earth geophysics, mantle dynamics, seismology, earthquakes and earth's rotation, and also GPU computing. radiative heat transfer, boundary-element method, subduction dynamics, high Rayleigh number convection. seismic tomography. There were some serious scientific discussions among the various groups of participants. The group was led on an excursion along the Dnieper River and the museum of technical history. The Ukranians displayed considerable hospitality. The abstracts were published by an Ukranian journal in geophysics. We plan to have another meeting like this in the next two years.
